QREC.LO_SHORT_DESCRIPT: You will learn about an article that focuses on the first snowfall in the North-Eastern regions of Albania.
QREC.KEY_WORDS: Diber district, snow, snowfall, winter, earthquake

QREC.OBJECTIVES: Understand a TV report while learning about important verb phrases related to weather.

QREC.POP_UP:
A note about definite and indefinite nouns in Albanian:

In Albanian, definiteness is not indicated by a separate word, but may be indicated by definite case endings on nouns. The usual indefinite article in Albanian is një (a; one), although the determiners ndonjë (some, any), ca (some), disa (several) may also indicate that the noun phrase they introduce is indefinite.

The indefinite noun is accompanied by the article një, especially when mentioned for the first time in a particular context.

On the other hand, in general, a common noun used in definite form has a specific referent, thought of as distinct from other members of the same class. A noun will be in definite form, when it has already been mentioned in a given context or, when the definite noun belongs to the speaker, the audience, or to some other obvious possesor, e.g.:  Mos flisni me zë të lartë se do më zgjoni djalin (don't talk aloud, or you will wake up my son [the son].

QREC.POP_UP:
There are two main dialects in Albania, Gheg and Tosk. The Gheg dialect is spoken mainly in the northern part of the country as well as in Kosovo.The Tosk dialect is spoken mainly in the southern part of Albania. The main difference between the two dialects is mainly phonetical. 

In this lesson (in the next activity) you will hear northern Albanians being interviewed. They are using the Gheg dialect. Listen carefully to both the original audio clip (Primary Audio)  and if you have difficulties, listen to the alternate audio in which standard Albanian is spoken. Note that Standard Albanian is based on the Tosk dialect.

The Gheg speakers employ phonological distinctions of vowel length and nasality, while Tosk  speakers do not. Ghegs preserve the n in many words in which Tosks have introduced r (which is kept in the Standard Albanian too).  The following are some examples of the differences between the Gheg dialect and the Standard Albanian:

Ai ka kënue (Gheg) vs. - Ai ka kënduar (Standard)

Also, Ghegs form infinitives with the preposition me while Tosks use the preposition për. For example:

Gheg: Shkova me pi ujë (I went to drink some water)

Standard: Shkova për të pirë ujë (I went to drink water).

In the video clip you will see me ushqyer (vs. për të ushqyer)

QREC.POP_UP:
In this activity you will become familiar with verb phrases related to weather. You will note that often they are not formed as they are in English. For example, in English people say I am cold (which is formed with the verb to be); in Albanian people say kam ftohtë (which is formed with the verb kam [to have]).

While in some cases you will note that these Albanian verb phrases may be formed similarly to their English counterparts, in many other cases they may be idiomatic. For example:

Jashtë bën ftohtë (it's cold outside). This is an idiomatic phrase in Albanian, and literally would translate: it makes cold outside.

Throughout this activity you will be able to learn these forms in context. Since this is an authentic interview, you can learn how people use these forms in real life.

QREC.FB:
ka rënë tërmeti - earthquake struck, lit: earthquake has fallen. Note that while Albanians use the present prefect tense for this time frame, English speakers use the simple past tense form (struck).

Ka rënë - v., pres. perf. tense, third pers., sing. This is an irregular verb. Its infinitive is bie (to fall).

Note that this same verb is used to describe other weather related phenomena, such as it rains  or it snows, for example:

bie borë, bie shi (pres. tense). Or, ka rënë borë, ka rënë shi (pres. perf. tense).

Note the translation of the entire sentence:

Kanë filluar reshjet e borës në qarkun e Dibrës veçanërisht në ato zona që ka rënë tërmeti si në komunën Ostren e Zefqan. (The snowfall started in the Diber district, especially in those areas where the earthquake struck such as the Ostren and Zefqan municipalities.)
QREC.STIMULUS: There are three words missing: a particle, a verb in present tense, and a noun.
QREC.FB:
A keni ftohtë? - Are you cold? or, Do you feel cold? Lit.: Do you have cold?

Usually Albanians use the particle a in front of the verb when asking questions.

Note that in Albanian, the personal pronoun ju (you) is omitted. That is because it is understood by the verb's person and number (sec. pers., plural). Also, note that in Albanain the verb kam (to have) is used, whereas in English the verb to be is used.

Pay attention to what the journalist says before he asks his question:

Kjo familje nuk ka ku të nezi as zjarr dhe as ka ku të gatuajë për me ushqyer fëmijët. (This family does not have the wherewithal to light a fire or to cook to feed the children.)

In standard Albanian this sentence would be:

Kjo familje nuk ka ku të ndezi as zjarr dhe as ka ku të gatuajë për të ushqyer fëmijët.

nuk ka ngjit - it hasn't stuck

This is the Gheg dialect. In Standard Albanian this would be: nuk ka ngjitur.

Ftohtë ban - it is cold. Lit. it makes cold.

In Standard Albanian this expression would be: ftohtë bën. Note that often you would hear this expression with the verb placed before the noun: bën ftohtë. Another form of expressing the same thing is: është ftohtë (it's cold). The difference between these two expressions is that the first one the verb bëj (to do/make) is used in the second one the verb jam (to be) is used.

Note that the man does not finish his first thought, and continues with the next: këtu s’kam as sobë ku të vëj...,  and then he says: fëmijtë i kam të ftohtë.

The following is a transcription of the Standarad version of this sentence. The changed words are underlined:

Ftohtë bën, këtu s’kam as sobë ku të vëj..., fëmijtë i kam të ftohtë, as një ndihmë, as një gjë, as nuk eshtë interesuar askush për të parë.

QREC.ACTY_DESCRIPTION: Understand details of the last part of the video clip.
QREC.POP_UP:
Albania has a pleasant Mediterranean climate with four distinct seasons. Summer is the peak tourist season, when people from the sweltering interior escape temperatures that can reach the high 30s (degrees Centigrade) in July.

In Tirana and other inland towns on the plains there is plenty of rainfall during the winter, but temperatures below freezing are rare. The high mountains as well as the town on the eastern part of the country often experience heavy snow between November and March. The best seasons in Albania are spring and autumn.
QREC.NOTE: Read the Teacher's Note to learn about the climate in Albania.
